channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Object Oriented Programming - OOP in Perl
item.description: You can read the book free of charge on this web site, or if you feel like supporting the writing of this book you can buy it and get a pdf and epub version of it.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.
item.dc:subject: Weekly collections

item.title: Property is Theft, Theft is Good
item.description: A clever, well-explained solution with a touch of humor. Perfect for those interested in optimization tricks and Perl’s practical elegance.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: In case of doubt, use a regex
item.description: A refreshing, regex-focused take on the problem that highlights Perl’s flexibility. Great for regex enthusiasts and those exploring unconventional solutions.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge : Week 328
item.description: A no-nonsense, efficient walkthrough of the weekly challenge. Ideal for those who prefer concise, performance-conscious solutions.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: A good question
item.description: A fun, well-written post that balances technical content with readability. Great for beginners and those who appreciate a casual yet informative take on coding challenges.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Good Replacement
item.description: While away, Rust is still the favourite choice for blog post. Code maintains clarity without sacrificing efficiency.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Questions are good
item.description: A no-nonsense, technically solid post that delivers working solutions with Perl best practices. Ideal for experienced developers who prefer code-first explanations.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Good Old-Fashioned Replacement Boy?
item.description: A masterclass in making technical content both educational and entertaining. Perfect for Perl enthusiasts who appreciate personality in programming tutorials.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Regexes Replacing All Good Strings?
item.description: A solid, well-explained solution with efficient implementations. Great for learners looking for clear, optimized Perl solutions to algorithmic problems.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 328
item.description: A thorough, well-written post that combines mathematical insight with practical coding solutions. Excellent for learners who want to understand both the "how" and "why" behind the challenges.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: regexs everywhere!
item.description: A technically excellent post that stands out for its rigorous mathematical approach and unique dual-language perspective.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Replace and Remove
item.description: A practical, no-frills post perfect for coders seeking quick solutions. It delivers correct and efficient code.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Kinda Pre-Disastered
item.description: A solid, enjoyable post that balances technical rigor with Dave’s signature conversational style. Ideal for Perl enthusiasts and coding challenge participants.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: All Good
item.description: The post is well-structured with a conversational tone, making it accessible to readers of varying skill levels.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: TWC328
item.description: Provides compact Perl implementations for each task. Avoids over-engineering (e.g., uses simple loops and hashes for uniqueness).
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: A Good String Is Irreplaceable
item.description: A strong, educational post with working code and creative problem-solving. The core is robust and instructive.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 328
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Replace all ?" and "Good String" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 329
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Counter Integers" and "Nice String". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Attending the Perl Community Conference (Hybrid) July 3-4
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Vibe coding a Perl interface to a foreign library - Part 2
item.description: An excellent resource for Perl developers needing to create robust, production-ready C library bindings. It has deep technical knowledge with practical implementation advice.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Vibe Coding a Perl interface to a C library
item.description: An excellent technical walkthrough for intermediate-to-advanced Perl programmers needing to interface with C libraries. It presents practical code with useful explanations of the binding process.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: TPRC Greenville 2025
item.description: A short and effective event report for TPRC 2025. If you missed the event then you must read this.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Keep on Mocking with a Key, Girrrrl
item.description: A fun, practical guide to mocking in Perl that balances humor with solid technical content. Ideal for Perl developers looking to improve their testing skills with minimal jargon.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Neural Networks and Perl
item.description: Stands out by exploring neural networks in Perl, a less common but intriguing combination. It provides a hands-on implementation.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: This week in PSC (197) | 2025-06-26
item.description: Another quick update from Perl Steering Council.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: Perl 5.42.0 Released: Performance Gains, Feature Refinements, and Key Security Fixes
item.description: The Perl development team has officially released Perl v5.42.0, introducing a blend of modern language features, thoughtful refinements to long-standing behavior, and a round of performance and security enhancements.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: Support Mohammad
item.description: This edition of the Perl Weekly newsletter was prepared by Mohammad Sajid Anwar. He has been editing every 2nd issue for 7 yeas already! Also, he has been running The Weekly Challenge for several years now. He does both of these in his free time because he loves doing them. However, it is really nice to know that there are 34 people who feel that his efforts are worth the recognition by supporting him with 5-10 USD / month via Patreon. If you are one of those people I'd like to thank you and if you are not yet, I'd like to encourage you to sign up to Patreon and start supporting him!
item.dc:subject: Sponsors

item.title: #728 - Perl Conference
item.description:
Hi there,

Last week was packed with two major gatherings for Perl enthusiasts: The Perl Community Conference (Hybrid) Summer 2025 and The Perl and Raku Conference 2025. Both events brought together developers, contributors and fans from around the world, whether in person or online.

Unfortunately, I couldn't attend either conference this time but I'm eager to catch up on what I missed. If you were there, I'd love to hear about your experience. Makoto Nozaki has already shared one: event report, thank you for that. If others have insights, talks or highlights to share, please do.

For those curious about the talks, the official PCC 2025 schedule is available here. I spotted a live talk link on Facebook and joined briefly, but due to audio issues, I had to drop out. Fingers crossed that recordings or slides will be shared soon for those of us who couldn't attend fully.

One thing, I noticed this year, there wasn't much pre-event promotion for individual talks or maybe I just missed it on social media? Either way, if you couldn't make it, keep an eye out for uploaded slides and summaries. There's always something new to learn!

That's all for now, enjoy the rest of the newsletter and happy coding..
item.dc:subject: Editorial
